Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of horse (part of head with mane and reins in added red remaining) to right.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to the EEF distribution list as well as Fairbanks, the sherd was found in the region of the Temple of Apollo. According to Robinson, which is then taken up in the CVA Boston II, the sherd was found in the region of the sanctuary of Hera.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 125, pl. XXXVIII, no. 351.7)
CVA Boston II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum USA, Fasc. 19, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (p. 4, pl. 108, no. 9)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 232, no. 182)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0967)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4826 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
